description: A radical energy reduction transformation of a 1920s home that adds a light-filled basement arranged around an atrium with living wall.

factsheet.heading: The challenge
paragraphs: 1920s houses are often a jumble of rooms  with no obvious flow and this home was no exception and had been made darker and more confusing with an ill-considered extension.  The house was large but with many under-utilised areas.

factsheet.heading: The brief
paragraphs: The brief was to create a low-energy home catering for future family needs that flowed freely to the garden while also providing more bedrooms, a gym and basement bar and cinema room.

factsheet.heading: How we created this unusual home
paragraphs: Creating a house that always had a view of the sky was key. In the entrance hall we removed a landing so that there is a view up into the new loft extension and this allows light to flood into the home from the moment you enter. The existing ground floor extension was removed and replaced with a larger building incorporating an atrium at its centre that allows daylight to flood into the basement rooms below.  The two-storey living wall accentuates the scale of this focal point in the house.

factsheet.heading: How we created a low-energy home
paragraphs: The significant refurbishment works allowed for low-energy improvements such as external wall and roof insulation, window replacement and solar PVs on the extension roof that increased the energy performance from SAP Band G to C.  The key improvement is to create a large house in which al the rooms are day-lit and naturally ventilated.  The arrangement of the house also creates a house for the future in which different generations of the family may live together.
